I hope an excerpt from my another answer should help here. “Education Technology” literally means slightly different than “Educational Technology” (EdTech). The first refers to the “education” as a technology. While the second refers to the “technologies of education” and “technologies for education”. “Technology of education” refers to the learning strategies, instructional strategies, pedagogies, etc. which aim at achieving a teaching-learning goal. “Technology for Education” refers to the external technologies such as Computers, Internet, Content Authoring tools, simulations, animations, manipulable objects, etc. These technologies can be integrated into a teaching-learning environment to aid the process of achieving any teaching-learning goal. A typical EdTech takes both of these aspects (Tech for Ed and Tech of Ed) together. To pursue this domain one needs to delve into the theories from Education, Psychology, Cognitive Science, Human Computer Interaction, design science, etc. This is a Socio-Tech domain, and the EdTech research requires employing the research methodologies from both Social Science and Technology. One of the prominent research methodology for EdTech research is Educational Design Research (EDR), which is further categorized as Design Based Research (DBR), Design Based Implementation Research (DBIR), Design and Development Research (DDR).
